commentBody:
Interesting theme and mostly good fill.

But this was Tuesday difficulty.

4/10

Matryoshka dolls are full of themselves.

(Wooden you agree?)
Gave me painful Lisp programming flashbacks but still, I admire the clever theme!
This might be one of my very favorite NYT puzzles ever. Diabolical to solve but done in three minutes under my average. Thank you for a truly excellent theme.
This Thursday puzzle was excellent! Wonderful nested design. Thank you!
Etoile and edam is rough, never heard of either );

Fun and well executed theme that actually helped with the solve. I wish there had been some way to clue the final answers, even in a very obtuse way, but that may be asking too much. My heritage is Russian and my grandmother had matryoshka dolls so it brought back fond memories. I disagree with George, no way this was Tuesday level, there were a fair number of easy clues but definitely a fair share of more difficult ones.
This is the kind of word play I come here for and thoroughly enjoy. I‚Äôd do a puzzle with this theme more often if it were offered. Loved it!

Love this theme!  It‚Äôs ‚ÄúCloud Atlas‚Äù in puzzle form.
In trying (not very hard) to find some other matryoshkas, I decided instead you could make your own. Take three four-letter words, say ALAN, STEM, RUSH. Nest them, and voil√†:

ALSTRUSHEMAN

your own artisanal matryoshka. It *could* mean something, right?

Other creations? Let‚Äôs hear them!
Even after getting the cross I was marveling that people apparently now apply to college using an APP üòÇ (I did understand it eventually).
nope

Ingenious theme that completely escaped me.  I solved the themed clues by waiting until I had enough crosses to see what the correct answer was without deciphering the parentheses.  I feel a little dirty.

I chuckled to see AKIRA Kurosawa pop up.  I just rewatched The Seven Samurai for the umpteenth time a couple of days ago.  The scene where the young samurai and the village girl forge their connection with a roaring fire distorting the space between them is one of my favorite cinematic moments ever.
Loved the nested clues idea! Great puzzle.
Excellent Thursday. Enjoyed it a lot!

Come on, seriously, this was way, way too easy for a Thursday.  A teeny bit better than last week's, but still just about all the cluing and the theme itself were all very, very simplistic.

What's going on?  I mean, the theme would have been cute for a Tuesday, sure.  But we've come to expect more challenge than this.  I don't know what to think.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)
Incredible theme that I did not even begin to grasp until well after I completed the puzzle
That was a lot of fun. Thanks:)

It wasn‚Äôt a rebus!!!  

Matryoshka dolls are a favorite of mine.  Two days in a row where the puzzle was a doable one for me!!  Yay!! I feel spoiled.
Great column Deb. Yes, life would be very boring if we all knew the same amount about the same things.
Perfect Thursday puzzle!
Interesting. But was there something I was supposed to tie together in the four phrases?  They seem completely unrelated to each other and the rest of the puzzle?
great puzzle, liked it a lot.

The nested clues seemed very easy (even easier with the Russian dolls clue...).  And no super obscure words or overly convoluted clues.  

Got it in record time (for me; for a Thursday), with no need to come here or to Google, and no groaning or swearing.  But , it was enjoyable - nice to have an approachable Thursday puzzle :).

I'd say

LOTHISVE

but that isn't actually a word of its own, lol. But I did love it! Left the theme entries blank / filled by crosses, as is my usual strategy with Shenanigans Afoot puzzles, but PEERREVIEW had me figuring it out, which helped  with the ones where I wasn't quite yet sure of the crosses. 

I'm sure there will be complaints but I found this fun.

GOJOBOD (which also isn't a word)

Did everyone‚Äôs ‚Äúsolve time distribution‚Äù graph get revamped? Hate that I can‚Äôt view the whole week with daily averages, current week‚Äôs and best solve time all in one bar chart. I liked being able to easily compare how I did!!
Great idea, fun puzzle!
That was SO much fun!

I think of all the carping that goes on in this forum, the most annoying one sniffing that "puzzles are just too simple now".

I know, I know, I'm a neophyte solver, but I think it's true that *constantly* being told that something is easy when one is failing at it.  

One of the things I *never* did as a chemistry professor is blithely over and over again how easy chemistry is, just because it was easy for me.  And I think it would have antagonized students had I done so.  It would have come across as arrogant.

If I follow others in simply giving up on this forum, it'll be because my blood pressure just gets too high when the "too easy" complaints come out.
I done did this puzz

Tricky, tricky Thursday. Well done, Mr. Brody. Every time I hear the word "toke", I think of this song, introduced by none other than Lawrence Welk as a "modern spiritual." I guess if you are Rastafari, maybe! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eKslYBMycHM

Fun puzzle with the nested clues.  And some fun figure-outs, like how there's lots of five letter things you carry into battle (SWORD, ARMOR, ETC) and lots of three letter Tolkien creatures (ELF, ORC, ENT) but only one combination that works together.

Does anyone else think that the Thursdays have been easier than the Wednesdays lately?  Last couple Wednesdays I've gotten 90% of the way but there's been one corner of the puzzle I'm completely lost.

The line uttered by the cartoon character in 64A (ELMER) is of course from the classic Warner Bros short "What's Opera, Doc." It was top of mind for me, as there was a performance of "Bugs Bunny at the Symphony" at the Hollywood Bowl last weekend, and I was in attendance (along with 10,000+ other people), and "What's Opera, Doc" concluded the show. As the conductor said, it's a great way to hear 18 hours of Wagnerian opera reduced to 6'47". It was also the first cartoon short to be inducted into the National Film Registry of the Library of Congress. Here's the cartoon in its entirety: - https://archive.org/details/whats-opera-doc_202210
38 across is a cover of Charles Aznavour‚Äôs song.

I enjoyed this puzzle right up to the time I got to the comments.

I was happy when I figured out the embedded clues.  I thought that was quite ingenious, especially given the word within a word within a word all made sense.

Then I hit the A in the cross of HAKE and MATRYOSHKADOLLS.

I wish I had a solution for the balance between the "too easy" people who would seemingly want the puzzles to be unsolvable  by 90% of solvers.  

I try not to complain when puzzles are too difficult for me.  I wish others wouldn't complain when they are too easy for them.
Diabolical without skimping on fun. Kudos to Sam!

Struggled with figuring out how the nestled clues were put together. Mainly got the answers by getting some acrosses clans my brain seeing the rest. Loved Time Machine. Don‚Äôt eat fish so not familiar with hake. I own 3 matryoshka dolls and had filled in the dolls before I looked at the clue. Then I also already had the y so when I would normally have questioned my spelling I was sure of it there. Solved the eastern hemisphere before the western hemisphere tonight.
I do Not like the new layout for average, this week, best time
Sam, this is masterful construction. Kudos!
I thought the revealer was going to be ‚Äúturducken‚Äù - the hen inside the duck inside the turkey.  But MATRYOSHKADOLLS was just as good.

There was a tied baseball game* last night. What a coincidence!

*more or less. The National League won in a tiebreaker.
(Promises (Gau (English, in web addresses) Airport) to pay)

I enjoyed this puzzle. In Polish the dolls are spelled MATRiOSzKA (sz being our equivalent of your sh sound). Of course I knew the Z would be an H in English, but it took me a moment to notice the I would be a Y.

I liked the theme. I thought it was well implemented.

I never played MYST but the title came to me. I had a similar experience with BAIDU. MOANA I learned from these puzzles. "There will be blood" I saw at the cinema when I still went there occasionally. It was a depressing mess I regretted watching, but at least it gave me one entry today. The enigmatic REN I got from crosses entirely.

I did not have major problems with my solve until I finally had to deal with the small area directly East. I have not seen Ted Lasso, and I still don't understand the 35D clue: "Words often appearing after a number and a hyphen." I desperately tried to parse 52A ("Word before foot, fire or free" as a single noun made up of two words, and nothing worked. I finally looked up TART_ to get the missing final letter, a T. This allowed me to finally understand 52A. 

I still don't get what INONE or its clue might mean (is it a golf thing?). Could somebody please explain it to me?

Having seen Francis's comment right below mine I'll be skipping today's other comments. There is little more annoying than a litany of "Too easy!!!" complaints, especially on a day I needed to look something up.
Puzzles don‚Äôt have to be hard but they do have to be fun, and this one was a lot of fun.  Great concept and some clever cluing.

Impressed with myself that I entered MATRYOSHKA DOLLS with just one O in the crosses. 

A fun puzzly puzzle. Smooth solve for me.
It was a fun puzzle. I finished it quickly since I paid zero attention to the theme (which I still don't know).

Thinking over the 'easy' vs 'hard' debate. First, I'll say that the most aggravating thing is people saying that a puzzle 'annoyed' them or that the constructor is 'showing off', etc. I mean... we're here to do puzzles? Which by definition require some thought to solve, and also by design require more thought on different days? If thinking is annoying, wow, you are in the wrong place. 

I'm much more likely to praise a well-constructed grid (on any day of the week), generally more so if the puzzle took me extra time with good wordplay. I think that's where some (most?) of the 'easy' comments are coming from - not from a place of denigration, but more like feedback ('I would have liked this to be harder '). So, today I liked the theme a lot, but would agree that's it an 'easy' Thursday, and that's just where I am in my solving journey. 

And for all the folks in the 'hard' camp - enjoy the journey! We've all been there. Keep on solving. Time spent solving matters - there's so much crossword-ese and convention to pick up on, and intuiting that is really key to cracking the late week puzzles. 99% of the sharp solvers are in no way looking down on you, perceived tenor of comments aside.

Fantastic idea for a puzzle, Mr. Brody! I've enjoyed MATRYOSHKA DOLLS even before I knew what they were called. (I vividly remember the set my friend Margaret had of Soviet and Russian leaders, Lenin encasing Stalin encasing Khrushchev on down to Yeltsin.)

I hate to imagine the work that went into finding the theme answers. I don't think one could write a program to do that.

It took me a bit to understand how the theme worked, and I mostly filled in what I could from the crosses in the hopes that eventually it would make sense. And I lost a little bit of time with beST as my [Yearbook superlative] (reminder to self: Always check the crosses!)

I loved this theme! Full marks for creativity. 

I had the joy of figuring out almost right away, and excitedly filled in a few of those downs right  off the bat. 

Does that make me better than anyone else? Definitely not. 

Does it mean I‚Äôm smarter? Nope. 

Could I unknowingly share a hive mind with the constructor? Undoubtedly!
In the spirit of REN and Stimpy, ‚ÄúNo sir, didn‚Äôt like it.‚Äù
Had to google the name of the Doll as I‚Äôve only known them by their nationality. Really clever idea, loved it.

I enjoyed seeing TIES clued as "baseball rarities" only two days after the MLB All-Star Game ended in a tie that had to be resolved via a mini home run derby. Now that's a fortuitous twist of puzzle timing!

@Deb Amlen

From the column:  ‚ÄúMaybe you knew about BAIDU. Maybe you‚Äôve even used it, if you read Mandarin.‚Äù

I knew about it, having lived in Hong Kong for seven years, but I didn‚Äôt use it.  My friends there use it, so this was a gimme for me. 

But I write here now to point out that Mandarin is a spoken dialect, not a written language.  It‚Äôs the ‚Äúofficial‚Äù dialect of mainland China, though there are also many other local dialects.  Cantonese is used in Hong Kong and in parts of nearby Guangdong province.  

Mandarin is also referred to as Putonghua (‚Äúcommon language‚Äù).

The written language is just called Chinese although the mainland uses a ‚Äúsimplified‚Äù form whereas HK and Taiwan use ‚Äútraditional‚Äù Chinese.   It‚Äôs not phonetic so the written character offers no clue to pronunciation in any dialect.  But far-flung Chinese can read each other‚Äôs writing though they may not understand a word spoken by the other. 

Mark

Delightful theme. Being obsessed with Bracket City lately I figured out the (somewhat similarish)  theme right off the bat and could get the answers without much trouble.
I grew up with Ukrainian immigrant grandparents so knew the revealer right away too, having spent my childhood (ok‚Ä¶and adulthood) playing with many a nesting doll. 
Having the five long theme answers in my first pass greatly helped the rest of my solve and I finished rather quickly for a Wednesday but the process didn‚Äôt feel too easy and definitely wasn‚Äôt boring. Really, really liked this one!!
I recently bought a dinner kit online and a main foodstuff in it was hake. Extra fun to find what would otherwise been a totally unknown word in the puzzle.

I liked this puzzle. Not too easy, but definitely not too difficult. One of those with a great "Aha!" moment that opened up the solve. I had fun trying to put the themers together from the clues, and crosses corrected where necessary.

No major problems with the vocabulary, although it took a couple crosses for me to remember BAIDU, which I'd seen references to in the past. I liked the clues for ATTIC and SEESAW, and was familiar with MYST and FILIAL. 

Very enjoyable. Thanks, Sam!

Amazing construction, Sam Brody! I guessed the theme from the clues early on, but I couldn‚Äôt quite work out the answers until I had way too many crosses. Felt like it took me forever to get the correct spelling on the revealer. I couldn‚Äôt wait to read the comments on this little gem. The drama department always sends at least a few representatives, but I‚Äôm happy to see that the majority found it as clever and fun as I did.

i cant remember the last time a thursday made me smile this much.
thanks, mr brody.
to someone like me who has never dipped a toe into the pool of crossword construction, todays offering fills me with an inchoate and fraught sense of how deep the pool is.
Omg I just got it!!!!  Fun!
Completed it in record time but still can‚Äôt grasp the theme. Oh well.  But we won trivia tonight!
A bit like peeling an onion. Layers and layers to go through shedding a few tears along the way. But cooked gently it turned out to be sweet and delicious.

Not to rub it in, but we were on the second row. 
@CCNY

Following up on yesterday‚Äôs conversation about Elvis Costello:

Not to rub it in, but we were in the second row for this most recent performance. 

We‚Äôve seen him about five times now, I think. He always puts on a great show. 

I *might* have seen Tom Waits in the 1970s, before I really knew who he was. I think he might have been on the bill in an outdoor show I went to in Dallas. 

Waits stopped playing Austin after a bad experience during SXSW, so by the time I became a fan, seeing him there wasn‚Äôt an option.

CHEWS before SHEDS. AIRATE before AIRDRY. TREE before SMOG. and I wanted SKI SLOPE before SEE SAW. I know I know doesn‚Äôt fit. 

Top tier was cute. 

I loved the theme. Amazing construction and the clues worked once I got the gimmick. I had a big smile solving. But I could not for the life of me remember the Russian name for the DOLLS. 

Thanks Sam Brody!!

I feel kind of bad that I solved this without having any idea how the theme worked. That was super cool.

On the plus side, I did spell ‚Äúmatryoshka‚Äù right on my first try.
I really enjoyed this one, a highly impressive piece of construction

Often I don't like the tricks in Thursday puzzles, but I really enjoyed this one, especially once I figured out that the answers to the parentheses made actual phrases and not word salad! Not my fastest, but not the slowest either. Several wrong turns for me (as others have noted, tree for smog, sole for hake) and a few blocked pipes in the brain till the coffee started working, (seriously, couldn't remember Jamie's surname for awhile there.. Duh.) but I made it through! 
Oddly Moana was called Vaiana originally here in the EU, though that has now changed (no idea why it was too begin with), but as my kid was Vaiana age when we watched it, that's stuck in my head still.

What kind of dolls now?  Yeesh!  7D almost put this out of reach.  Not knowing the dolls and having some difficulty with the crosses I was starting to get frustrated but managed to figure it out in a time that was 27% longer than average.

I totally missed some easy clues i.e. I'm a Lasso fan and Excel user but totally scored own goals and divide by zero errors with those ones. Managed to get peerreview with crosses after flirting with Erie but trying to solve those cluescluesclues with just my brain and a thumb proved too much without either pen and paper or a whiteboard at hand too.

I loved this puzzle. I did have to look up the spelling of the revealer, and even after understanding the theme, I relied way more on the crosses than the themed clues. 

Delightfully challenging!
Amazing theme! Laughed out loud when i got it

Late solve since I'm currently in Europe and sleeping when it comes out. 11 minutes, theme came to me pretty easily, and I'd definitely call it something that was actively useful in solving. I would not have gotten APPS MYSTS BAIDU or TOKE without it. Or at least would have struggled to play around with those. I will call "foul" on TIES being a baseball rarity. In MLB, I do believe that they are an impossibility, at least under current rules. I'm not sure about other leagues, but in leagues that do not utilize extra innings, they're not particularly rare. Maybe I'm neglecting some leagues where ties can only occur due to rain abandonment
Loved this, thank you! A fun theme and happily I worked it out on the first matryoshka entry and enjoyed figuring out the rest.

Just wow.  My head hurts from even attempting to understand how a human brain can construct a puzzle like this.  OR WAS IT AI??? JK.  Great job, Sam Brody . . . and how kind of you to offer to mentor new constructors.  Excellent Thursday adventure.
Lovely Thursday! Very light on the trivia, and the theme made solving considerably easier - it was straightforward, yet delightful. Thanks Sam! One of my quickest Thursdays, with no lookups :)

Who else had TOtE instead of TOKE? Toting is not quite dragging, but close enough that I didn't give it a second thought. Crossing that with a Japanese name I didn't know spelled my doom. The rest was doable but in the end he got me fair and square!
LOVED it.

The maker of a Thursday puzzle has a hard challenge: to make it interesting without being so difficult that it infuriates the majority of the solvers.

Great job here. Today was fun, with a very clever theme and construction, yet also well within the expected range of difficulty (coming squarely between my best and average times for Thursday), and not too many answers that lead one asking, "Who ever heard of that?"

I've spent many happy hours playing with MATRIOSHKADOLLS with my granddaughter (you never know what a given child will find fascinating), so it didn't take long to delete TREE for 6A and fill in the revealer.

Today is one of those unusual days where I really need to be at the office right at 8:30, or even a few minutes before, so it's good to wrap up the puzzle section of the morning's activities in plenty of time.

Thanks for a fun puzzle!

Just because we‚Äôre old, why do they call where were found the BADLANDS? Pure ageism.

Nice puzzle.
Loving the value-for-money today. What‚Äôs the NYT record for clues-per-answer?
Very well crafted. Great Thursday puzzle. Loved the nesting clues.

I haven't read the comments yet, but I'm just going to barge in and say I found this to be quite the clever entertaining puzzle for a number of reasons. I'll bet anything I have to say has already been said. 

One thing I'd like to ask. In Spain and Argentina merluza is a fish you are always going to find on the menu and the English translation is almost always HAKE. I have never seen HAKE on a menu in the United States, never seen it for sale in a fish market, never saw a recipe for it, just do not recognize the word.

Maybe it's a British thing? I don't know, maybe someone would be kind enough to enlighten me. I think it's basically a cod, but I really don't know.
Aaaarrrrggggh!

Chewy and chipper!

Saw the spanner and thought,
if this is, in fact, MATRIOSHKA DOLLS,
there will be far less complaints.

Then, it just 
look at the clue,
look at the grid,
back to the clue,
back to the grid‚Ä¶

Insanely clever.
Thank you Sam!

And Eric Hougland, the zeitgeist!
Or Badger-Meinhof?
I dunno. Something, anyway.
Fun puzzle! Once I got 7 Down it all fell into place. Very creative!
Superb Thursday. Very clever and entertaining!
Everything a Thursday puzzle should be.

If you like puzzles like the theme answers in this puzzle, The Atlantic just started a free one called Bracket City. Having played it for a few weeks is the reason I was able to solve this puzzle as quickly as I did!
I loved this one. More Sam Brody please!
Perfect Thursday puzzle. I wasn't sure how to spell MATRYOSHKA, but I loved the theme.

If I'm going to gripe about annoying themes (and you know I am), I've got to praise the enjoyable ones. Clever, fun, and helpful toward solving. I was able to get this at one sitting. Nice job, Sam Brody.

Wow, wow, wow!  Kudos to Mr. Brody!  I‚Äôm constantly amazed at the cleverness and creativity of constructors who create these puzzles for our enjoyment, and I‚Äôm grateful that they share their gifts with us.  Just amazing!
I don‚Äôt usually (or ever) comment on puzzles, but this one was particularly fun and clever. I have to praise the constructor for coming up with this one!

Here‚Äôs an idea for a future NYT Thursday puzzle: Employ the ‚Äútight‚Äù theme set concept, but all the answers must be the names of rap artists or their songs, in languages other than English (but 12th-century English ok), famous Bollywood actresses and tree genera. Lots of other possibilities!

Clever theme, handled very well. All the vertical thematic entries seemed very solid. 

Got the theme and all the themers quickly ... and then struggled in the top center since I couldn't remember the name of the Russian dolls!

Having AIROUT instead of AIRDRY didn't help. Silly mistake there, since "outdoors" is in the clue. I'm also strangely unfamiliar with HAKE, "There Will Be Blood", and Elvis Constello songs.

Can't find a NIT to pick in this fine grid. My only remaining question is an etymological one: When/how did ETOILE lose any hint of the S that must have been there in the original Latin? Where's Oikofuge when we need him?

Well... I'm the winner of the Bitzer Prize today. I'm just more than a bit surprised to find out that I'm apparently the only one who has never heard of MATRYOSHKADOLLS. Anyway... that pretty much doomed any chance I had at this one. No big deal. And.. MATRYOSHKADOLLS was an answer once before - in a Friday puzzle from December 28, 2018 by David Steinberg. That was the last bottom crossing answer.. at 59a. And the clue for that was... "Things that contain 59-Across that contain 59-Across that ..." That puzzle actually had grid crossing triple stacks at the top and bottom of the puzzle. The stack at the top was: LEADEROFTHEPACK ALFAROMEOSPIDER GOINGBACKTOCALI And the other two at the bottom: ALAINRENELESAGE ALLOVERCREATION Don't think I would have much of a chance at that one either. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=12/28/2018&g=59&d=A Might be time to think about returning to my home planet. ...
This was one terrific puzzle.
I know Erykah BADU but not BAIDU.  But the crosses weren‚Äôt hard.  Anyway, congratulations to Sam Brody for a great Thursday!
Nice one, thumbs up Sam!

Terrific puzzle ‚Ä¶ 

Thanks Mr Brody!!

Congratulations to all those who could spell 7D. without looking it up!
Nice placement of three letter fills to help figure things out.
I was ready to give up but the S.E. corner gave me impetus to continue.
Incredible construction!
At first, I thought maybe it was already Friday, but I hung in and really enjoyed this one!
Kinna ez.
This was hard for me. Still enjoyed it. Thanks!

Fantastic puzzle! I've been doing these for a while but this is my first time completing a Thursday without peeking at the help column.
The theme doesn't feel gimmicky and was really satisfying to figure out. Not too many US-specific references, which definitely helped this non-native English speaker (although it took me an embarrassingly long time to get ETOILE, so I really shouldn't use that as an excuse).
I usually skip Fridays and Saturdays, but with this newfound (inflated, no doubt) sense of confidence, I might give them a go this week!
Great puzzle. Challenging and fun.

Hands up if, to remember the name of the Ted Lasso character, you started singing JAMIE TARTT doo doo doo doo doo, a la Baby Shark.

Overall, a clever theme. I enjoyed solving the clues within the clues. They were not too hard, but my difficulty was figuring out which order to put them in, until I realized that the answers were nested within each other. Brilliant!

Otherwise, there were some very challenging clues that were easily accessible from the crosses. Finished in less than average time, which is saying something for a Thursday. A great mental workout. Offerings like these are why I look forward to Thursdays.

This is my favorite Thursday puzzle of the year! I love the cleverness of the theme and difficulty level of the construction. I was tempted to look up the spelling of 7D, but just kept working the puzzle. I made educated guesses about stuff I didn‚Äôt know and managed to solve it without lookups just a slight bit over my average time. The NE corner almost did me in with 10D and 12D (which I didn‚Äôt know), but I finally thought of TOKE (16A)! I also didn‚Äôt know 14A in the NW corner, but managed to get it on the crossings. What a satisfying solve! I have a four-day streak going!

A nearly perfect Thursday puzzle (and I say *nearly* because perfection isn‚Äôt possible among us mortal). It was challenging but not so much it tempted me to throw in the towel and start looking things up. I had no idea how to spell MATRYOSHKA DOLLS, though I knew what they were‚Ä¶the first time I ever saw one was on the mantel in my maternal grandmother‚Äôs apartment, but we called them Russian DOLLS, which I initially tried but soon realized that it had far too few letters. I got the concept but didn‚Äôt really use it to solve (used crossing clues and intuition) and it was only after I got the star that I went back and really appreciated the theme. Bravo to Sam Ezersky.
Wow. 10 minutes longer than average, and proud of myself!

Brilliant construction and exactly the right degree of difficulty.  The only thing I wish had been included would have been a clue solving to Natasha Lyonne, star of the wonderful steaming series (at least in Season 1) Russian Doll.

The theme was riveting. Having written code in my past life, the nested parens are easy to read, yet very tricky to work their solution into the grid. I gave in to the solutions not being actual words, as we've seen in past puzzles. The ‚Äútime machines‚Äù finally did it for me.

The ‚ÄúPack animal‚Äù solution‚Ä¶ what a low blow after yesterday‚Äôs horrendous profanity we were *forced* to endure. Nice stab, Mr. Brody! On the brighter side, at least yesterday prepared me for assam.

‚ÄúSmall sticking point‚Äù was a gimme because, well, uh, reading Wordplay comments, err, um‚Ä¶

I'll have to peruse the comments to figure out ‚Äúinone,‚Äù which still stumps me.

The ‚Äúairout‚Äù and ‚Äútree‚Äù 404s definitely hindered the messy pet solution. Once I corrected ‚Äútree,‚Äù I was mortified to see sh**s. Funny, I knew the flaky fish, but not the ‚Äúout of cite.‚Äù

I don't see the ‚Äúsea‚Äù being a sphere, more like an expanse. Although I've not seen Cpt Jack Sparrow sporting an orb, maybe Blackbeard buried several?

I think it's one of the NY solvers here‚Ä¶ B, maybe? The emu filler with Jesse Goldberg‚Äôs puzzle of the year guy‚Ä¶ I remember doing that one, and I agree. Does today replace Jesse‚Äôs standing?

What a wonderful puzzle!  I didn't mind having my brain twisted into a pretzel to start with...it's kinda cool to find out that there ARE new things under the sun.  Personally, I'm fond of parenthetical phrases, although (ahem, Sam) one could carry it a bit too far...  

I have just one tiny "compact wooden figure" surviving from my Russische Holzpuppe...  (the kind with the multiple twisted spellings.)  It resides with other wee keepsakes in a printer's drawer hung on the wall.  (If you move alot, you learn that anything of size isn't going to survive; "three moves equal one fire," the saying goes.)

funny enough, I got the theme quickly but didn't use it much to solve. Didn't love the NIT/TARTT cross for people like me that haven't seen the show- I felt that NIB fit the clue just fine. Maybe just a small sticking point!
Why no Comments available on the Spelling Bee Forum?? Please fix.

I love a good Thursday--thanks Sam Brody & eds.!

Too bad for me I knew neither HAKE nor how to spell MATRYOSHKA. I had piKE as the flaky white fish for a while, but luckily pets SpEDding all over your furniture isn't a thing.

Really enjoyed this one!

Fun! The MATRYOSHKADOLLS took me on a TIMEMACHINE back to when I was in college, in 1985-- I was a Russian minor. It was the only language that would fit in my heavy pre-med lab schedule the first semester, and I stuck with it.

My fianc√© and I wanted to take a summer course with our professor to the then USSR, and my parents said they'd pay for that or our wedding. I think it was $2k apiece.

We chose the trip, of course, and it was fantastic! The famous landmarks but also the people. Met a couple of  Russian med students and hung out with them while they pointed out the KGB cars. Drank homemade bathtub cherry vodka in the apartment of a refusnik pediatrician and got her some groceries at the tourist shop she wasn't allowed to enter. Learned not to speak Russian in the Lithuanian shops. Took a bus through the Caucasus mtns driven by a man drunk on grappa-- gorgeous and terrifying! I am sad for the Russian people suffering under Putin, the ones who oppose him.

I got my wedding dress at the mall for $80, my dad took our photos, and we had cake with a few friends-- just fine. We divorced after 33 yrs when he had a new understanding of himself, but we are friends and he still has the matryoshka dolls we brought back!

Hi! New commenter here, can help with your etymology question :
"When/how did ETOILE lose any hint of the S that must have been there in the original Latin?"

The correct spelling is "√©toile" (the accented capital E is a pain to achieve on most keyboards!) That accent is a typographical reminder of the "s" that sloughed off over the years, which can still be found in words that share the Latin root (e.g. "stellaire", stellar). The Old French spelling (up until 15th-16th century) was "estoille" or "esteille". Similar phenomena happened with the words "h√¥pital", "for√™t", etc.
